headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Shark Attacks Over the Last Few Weeks; Sebastian Maniscalco is Interviewed about His New Movie; How Americans Spend Memorial Day Holiday. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: An American woman is in serious condition this morning after reportedly losing her leg in a shark attack. This happened when she was snorkeling Wednesday in the Turks and Caicos. It is the latest in a string of shark attacks we've seen in the past week or so.Joining us from Rockaway Beach, right here in New York, is our Miguel Marquez, who has not yet seen a shark, yet, thank goodness. But People are a little nervous on the coast, right?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank goodness. I'm glad they're going to be OK. But, still, a lot of scares all in just a few weeks.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Miguel, thanks very much. Appreciate it.Erica.

utterances.speaker: ERICA HILL, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: This morning, a California man is free from prison after serving 33 years for a crime prosecutors now say he did not commit. Daniel Saldana was convicted in 1990 of trying to murder six high school students. He was one of three men charged and he was sentenced to 45 years to life. The district attorney's officer, however, began investigating after learning in February that another convicted attacker told authorities Saldana was not involved. Well today, as you can imagine, Saldana says he's grateful to be free.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DANIEL SALDANA, EXONERATED AFTER SERVING 33 YEARS IN PRISON: I just knew that one day this was going to come. I'm just so grateful. I just thank God, and Jesus. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Saldana, who was working construction at the time of the shooting, says he has no idea why he had been linked to that crime.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, coming up, a little treat for you. Comedian Sebastian Maniscalco, known for his hilarious takes on family life, is taking his relationship with his own father to the big screen starring alongside Robert de Niro.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ROBERT DE NIRO, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: A Maniscalco always finds a way to feed his family.

utterances.speaker: SEBASTIAN MANISCALCO, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: My father has an old Italian saying -(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Sebastian Maniscalco joins us next.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) [08:40:32] HILL: Father's Day is now just a couple of weeks away. And through it's never too early to start thinking about what would maybe put a smile on your dad's face. It could be especially challenging if your father is, for example, Salvo, a Sicilian American played by Robert de Niro in a new film, "About My Father." (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my girl!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, what a beauty.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Elie belly.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You know, looking back at this, my dad had to be overwhelmed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And he's a little handsy, huh?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's called love and affection, dad. Unlike you when you met me at the delivery room and chose to shake my hand.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What else was I supposed to do? We just met. Huh?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Guys, come on, I want you to meet Sebastian's father.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hey, Sebastian.Hi, nice to see you. A pleasure. Welcome.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Nice to meet you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Sebastian, so good to see you.And you must be the charming Salvo.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So nice to finally meet you in person, Tina (ph). It's just last week I was checking out your highlights on TV.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, the CNN or the Fox ones?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No, no, the blonde ones. Your hair, if I could say, is just like a block of marble I want to sink my tools into it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hey, hey, hey, what are you doing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Sorry, I -(END VIDEO CLIP) HILL: "About My Father" is out today nationwide. Comedian and actor Sebastian Maniscalco wrote the film and stars in it and joins us now. Great to have you with us. So, we see Salvo there played by Robert de Niro. It was actually based on your dad, Salvo, also a hairdresser. I'm curious, did this film actually put a smile on your dad's face? SEBASTIAN MANISCALCO, COMEDIAN/WRITER, "ABOUT MY FATHER": Oh, yes. My father didn't really believe that de Niro was going to play him in this. You know, when I told him, he's like, yes, right, I'll believe it when I see it. And then my dad got a phone call from Bob and he wanted to hang out with him, you know, for a weekend so he could do script analysis with my dad. So, my dad flew down to Oklahoma and was teaching Robert de Niro how to, you know, speak Italian. And I was like, this is something that I never thought would be in the pipeline. I mean, I had de Niro posters on my wall growing up, and here he is, my dad teaching him how to - how to be him. And my dad asking me, am I getting paid for this? I'm like, what?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Wait, are you saying your dad didn't get paid for that? You didn't pay him?

utterances.speaker: MANISCALCO
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, I - no -- nobody paid him. I had to take it out of my till. So -- so, yes, it - it was - it was - it's been fun. I mean it's been a wild ride. My parents, my mother and my father and -- are able -- you know, I'm just happy they're alive so they're, you know, sharing this experience with me because we're such a tight family. And for me to share this with them is a big moment.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: It's - it's pretty great, I have to say. The film is - the film is super fun.For people who -- I want to get people who should be familiar with you at home, but if they're not, just a sense too of, you know, a lot of this for people who are familiar with your comedy will feel a little bit familiar because so much of what you talk about is about your upbringing, is about your own Sicilian father. So, I just want to play a little bit of those moments. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MANISCALCO
utterances.sentences: The world doesn't match my upbringing, OK? I'm here to tell you that. I grew up with an immigrant family. My father's Sicilian. My mother's Italian. I got to - I got to clarify that, all right? Half Sicilian, half Italian. But if you talk to my father, you're Sicilian, you're Sicilian. OK, dad, relax.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: There's so much in this movie -- it's about the culture clash when families meet, which is relatable for a lot of couples, a lot of families. But as you were writing this, you got your Sicilian father, right, that this is base on, and this very blue blood, very waspy family on the other side. How close is that to your real life?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: When we see these families, I think it's also in many ways, so correct me if I'm wrong, it felt like a love letter, too, to your dad, and maybe even to your in-laws?

utterances.speaker: MANISCALCO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think it definitely is. You know, the fact that I was able to give my father a movie, it's not something every kid gets a chance to do. And, you know, my father is my toughest critic and my biggest fan at the same time, you know? Coming from an immigrant family, work was really stressed in our house. It was like no one's ever going to give you nothing. You got to work for every -- every piece of food that you get.You know, he's been on my back for 49 years. This guy's relentless, you know? He - he's still at my shows going, you know, you got any new material? What's -- you know, let's start writing some new stuff. You know, people want to see new stuff. SO, it's nice to kind of have that voice on my shoulder, although annoying at times, sometimes I need it.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: I think we all talk about as we get older, and we look at our own kids, and we end up - we have these moments where you think, oh, my God, I'm doing exactly what my parents did.Are you Salvo in real life with your own kids?

utterances.speaker: MANISCALCO
utterances.sentences: There's hints of it. You know, I think what we do as parents, we take from what our parents did to us and we cherry pick. You know, oh, like, I like the fact that my father gave me chores growing up. I was cutting the lawn, washing the car, vacuuming the living room, and now I got my three-year-old making his bed, cleaning his plate, you know. I want to instill that type of work ethic my father instilled in me.So, the way my father delivers a message to me, his criticisms, are very unfiltered, raw and sometimes not nice, you know? And it's hard to hear sometimes. But, you know, in talking to my kids, I've taken a different approach. You know, I'm still stern and firm, but there's a little bit of love sprinkled in there.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Sebastian Maniscalco, the film definitely has a lot of love sprinkled through it, a lot of humor, too, great to have you with us this morning and congrats on the film. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MANISCALCO
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me. I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Can't wait to see it.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Out today. There you go.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Out today. Can I take the kids? No.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Maybe - maybe Sienna.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: A little young. A little young. A little young.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Maybe.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, Memorial Day weekend kicking off. What is expected to be really a busy travel season this summer. You are looking at live pictures from the Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport in Atlanta. So, how are most Americans spending the weekend?Ooh!

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, there's our boy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Name -- wait, wait, wait, name the movie. Name the movie, Harry. What movie is this song from?You don't know. How does Harry not know? I feel like you know what all movies and all music.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Memorial Day, a federal holiday for Americans to honor the men and women who died serving in the military so that we could remain free. So, how are Americans using their time off?Senior data reporter Harry Enten is here with this morning's number. Good morning.

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENGEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Good morning.All right, so this morning's number is 90. Why? Because Memorial Day is a paid day off for 90 percent of all U.S. workers. It's one of the top holidays for getting a day off. And more than that, Americans believe that it should be a day off. So, this is a great question that was asked, should be a national holiday, 82 percent of Americans believe it should be a national holiday. That is tops of any holiday. Beats out New Year's Day at 80 percent and Labor Day at 76 percent.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: There we go. So their wish came true, they get their national holiday.The big question for a lot of people is, what are you doing this weekend?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: How are you spending the weekend? For many people it's the official kickoff to summer. So, what are we up to?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: So, what are we up to? OK, the top Memorial weekend day plans, relax or do nothing, number one. I like that one. That is great. Number two, see family. Number three, a cookout, obviously. A Memorial Day weekend cookout.So, what are you going to cook? What are Americans' favorite foods to grill on the barbecue? Beef is number one at 39 percent. Then you get chicken at 27 percent. Pork, 11 percent. Veges, 10 percent. Fish, 10 percent. That's a little too healthy for me, I think.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Those are my top two.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: That's why you look so great. I've got to use your secrets.But of course I think the real question is, when does summer unofficially start? Memorial Day holiday comes in number one at 45 percent, schools let out at 41 percent. Twenty years ago I would have said that was the answer. Or whenever I take a vaca, 10 percent. If that were the case, I would, in fact, never have a start to summer because I never take off.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are you working - you're working Monday?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: No, I'm -- I'm taking off.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: See, stop complaining.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: No, I like to complain. It's my Jewish way.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: But that's what he does best. It's what he does best.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, he does. Harry, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, pro snowboarder Kevin Pearce was just 22 years old when a catastrophic snowboarding accident derailed his Olympic dreams. In 2009 he suffered a traumatic brain injury while he was training in Utah. His older brother, Adam, stayed by his side throughout his recovery and together they found yoga and Adam says he watched his brother come back to life. Now Adam brings yoga to other traumatic brain injury survivors and that makes him a CNN hero.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ADAM PEARCE, CNN HERO
utterances.sentences: I think people feel isolated after a brain injury because they don't feel able.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's hard. I've lost my identity.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And for more on Adam's work go to cnnheroes.com. While you're there, nominate your own hero.Thank you so much for joining us this Friday. Thank you for being here. I'll see you next week.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: My pleasure. Enjoy your weekend.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks. A little bit of a long weekend. I'll be off Monday, but I will see you Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Well-deserved. I'll see you Tuesday.
